assessment_meta.title: Complete OCEAN Behavioral Analysis
assessment_meta.description: Comprehensive personality and behavioral assessment covering all life domains - work, relationships, personal growth, and wellbeing

instructions.intro: This comprehensive assessment explores how you think, feel, and behave across different life situations. Your responses help create a rich profile of your personality patterns.
instructions.response_format: Scenario-based: Choose the response that best matches how you'd naturally act
instructions.time_guidance: Take your time - most people need 15-25 minutes. You can pause and return anytime.
instructions.privacy_note: Questions are classified by privacy level. Some workplace patterns may be shared with employers (aggregated only), while personal questions remain private to you.

questions.text: Your friend group is planning something you don't want to do, but everyone else seems excited. You:

options.text: Go along with it to avoid being difficult
Make an excuse to get out of it
Suggest an alternative that works for everyone
Honestly say it's not for you

questions.text: At a party, you typically:

options.text: Stay close to the people you came with
Find one person to have a deep conversation with
Help the host with things to stay busy
Work the room and talk to lots of people

questions.text: You made a mistake at work that no one noticed yet. You:

options.text: Wait to see if anyone notices first
Quietly fix it and hope no one finds out
Confide in a trusted colleague for advice
Immediately tell your boss and own up to it

questions.text: You're decorating your living space. What actually happens?

options.text: It stays pretty bare - decorating isn't your thing
Keep it minimal and functional
Display lots of photos and memories
Carefully curate art, colors, and textures that inspire you

questions.text: It's 11 PM and you planned to wake up early tomorrow. A new episode of your favorite show just dropped. You:

options.text: Stay up watching - you'll figure it out tomorrow
Watch 'just one episode' (but actually watch three)
Set a timer for 30 minutes as a compromise
Stick to your plan and go to bed

questions.text: A family member regularly makes comments that hurt your feelings. You:

options.text: Try to develop thicker skin and not let it bother you
Limit your time around them
Make comments back to show them how it feels
Tell them directly how their comments affect you

questions.text: When you walk into a room full of people you don't know well, you:

options.text: Wait for someone to approach you
Find something to do (get a drink, check your phone)
Look for someone you recognize to join
Introduce yourself to whoever seems approachable

questions.text: You're going through something difficult emotionally. Who actually knows about it?

options.text: Nobody - you handle things privately
You hint at it but don't give details
One or two very close people
Anyone who asks how you're doing

questions.text: When listening to music, what's your actual pattern?

options.text: Music is mainly background noise while doing other things
Whatever's on the radio or popular
Stick to your favorite playlists from years ago
Actively seek out new artists and genres

questions.text: Your room/workspace is getting messy. When do you actually clean it?

options.text: You function fine in chaos
Only when it's unbearable or someone's coming
Weekly cleaning routine
Keep it clean daily - mess bothers you

questions.text: Someone consistently asks you to do favors that are inconvenient for you. You:

options.text: Keep saying yes but feel increasingly overwhelmed
Help them find alternative solutions
Explain why the requests are difficult for you
Start saying no more often

questions.text: At a team meeting, one person is dominating the conversation and others are clearly uncomfortable. You:

options.text: Wait for someone else to say something
Try to redirect with a question to the group
Directly address the imbalance
Step up and suggest a way forward

questions.text: Someone compliments you genuinely. What's your real internal reaction?

options.text: Feel uncomfortable and change the subject
Wonder what they want from you
Deflect or minimize it immediately
Accept it gratefully and feel good

questions.text: You're daydreaming during a boring meeting. Where does your mind actually go?

options.text: You rarely daydream - you stay focused on the present
Practical plans for your upcoming tasks
Replaying recent conversations and events
Elaborate scenarios of alternative lives you could be living

questions.text: You're working from home with a deadline. What's your actual pattern?

options.text: Get distracted every 10 minutes
Procrastinate until panic sets in
Work in bursts with lots of breaks
Focused work until it's done

questions.text: Two of your friends are in a heated argument in front of you. You:

options.text: Feel uncomfortable and look for an excuse to leave
Stay neutral and let them work it out
Suggest they take a break and cool down
Try to mediate and help them find common ground

questions.text: In group conversations, you tend to:

options.text: Listen more than you speak
Ask questions to understand others better
Share stories and experiences
Try to keep the conversation flowing

questions.text: Your deepest insecurity gets triggered in conversation. What actually happens?

options.text: You shut down or leave the conversation
You get defensive or aggressive
You deflect with humor or change topics
You acknowledge it's a sensitive area for you

questions.text: Someone suggests trying an improv comedy class together. What's your real reaction?

options.text: Make an excuse - that's way outside your comfort zone
Suggest something else you'd prefer instead
Anxious - but you'll try it for the experience
Excited - you love trying creative challenges

questions.text: You set a personal goal (exercise, reading, meditation, etc.). What actually happens over the next month?

options.text: Forget about it within a week
Strong start, then gradually fade
Inconsistent but keep trying
Follow through consistently

questions.text: Someone takes credit for your idea in a group setting. You:

options.text: Let it slide to avoid creating tension
Address it privately with them later
Start documenting everything for future reference
Immediately speak up: 'Actually, that was my suggestion'

questions.text: Your team is stuck on a decision and everyone is looking around waiting for someone to take charge. You:

options.text: Suggest we take a break to think it over
Wait to see if anyone else will lead
Ask what everyone thinks we should do
Step up and suggest a way forward

questions.text: You realize you were wrong in an argument. What actually happens next?

options.text: Double down to avoid looking weak
Slowly change your position without admitting fault
Admit it privately later when things calm down
Immediately admit it and apologize

questions.text: When reading books or watching movies, what actually draws you in?

options.text: You rarely read or watch anything for pleasure
Feel-good stories with clear happy endings
True stories and documentaries about real events
Complex, ambiguous stories that make you think

questions.text: You have multiple tasks due. How do you actually handle them?

options.text: Panic and do them all last minute
Jump between tasks based on mood
Do the easy ones first to feel productive
Make a list and work through systematically

questions.text: The group is enthusiastically supporting an idea you think is fundamentally flawed. You:

options.text: Go along with it to maintain group harmony
Stay quiet but prepare for when it fails
Ask probing questions to help them see the issues
Respectfully present your concerns

questions.text: In a group discussion, you have a great point to make but several people are talking. You:

options.text: Let the moment pass rather than interrupt
Wait for a natural pause in conversation
Gesture or say 'excuse me' to get attention
Jump in when you can find an opening

questions.text: You're angry about something. How long does it actually last?

options.text: Days - you hold onto things
Hours - need time to cool down
Depends entirely on what it's about
Minutes - you process and move on

questions.text: A coworker shows you their hobby artwork during lunch. What's your genuine response?

options.text: Feel uncomfortable - you don't know how to respond to art
Compliment it politely and change the subject
Share your own creative pursuits in return
Get genuinely interested and ask about their process

questions.text: You get an urge to buy something you want but don't need. What actually happens?

options.text: Buy it immediately - life's short
Research extensively then probably buy it
Wait 24-48 hours to see if you still want it
Talk yourself out of it successfully

questions.text: A friend consistently shows up late and cancels plans last minute. You:

options.text: Accept it as part of who they are
Stop making plans with them without explanation
Make jokes about their lateness to hint at the problem
Tell them directly how their behavior affects you

questions.text: During an argument, the other person starts raising their voice and getting aggressive. You:

options.text: Feel overwhelmed and shut down
Walk away until they calm down
Stay calm and speak more quietly
Match their energy and get louder too

questions.text: Someone asks 'How are you?' when you're really not okay. What do you actually say?

options.text: 'Fine' - always, regardless of truth
'Surviving' - hint without details
Depends entirely on who's asking
'Not great actually' - you're honest

questions.text: Someone shares an unusual creative idea with you. What's your honest internal reaction?

options.text: Immediately think of practical obstacles
Skeptical - but you listen politely
Inspired to share your own weird ideas
Intrigued - you want to understand their vision

questions.text: Your phone buzzes while you're trying to focus. What's your actual behavior?

options.text: Check immediately every time
Try to ignore but usually fail
Check at planned intervals
Phone stays in another room when focusing

questions.text: Your group has inside jokes and references that a new member doesn't understand. You:

options.text: Continue with the group flow
Pull them aside later to catch them up
Suggest moving to topics everyone can follow
Make sure to explain the context to them

questions.text: You're in a meeting where everyone is agreeing with the boss's bad idea. You:

options.text: Nod along like everyone else
Ask clarifying questions that expose the problems
Find a diplomatic way to raise concerns
Stay quiet but prepared for failure

questions.text: Someone accuses you of something you didn't do in front of others. You:

options.text: Feel humiliated and don't know what to say
Get angry and attack their credibility
Calmly state the facts and ask to discuss privately
Immediately defend yourself loudly and clearly

questions.text: How do you actually engage with beauty in everyday life?

options.text: Too busy or distracted to notice most of the time
Occasionally appreciate beauty when it's obvious
Often stop to notice beautiful moments (sunsets, architecture, etc.)
Actively seek out beautiful experiences

questions.text: You're trying to break a bad habit. What's your actual success pattern?

options.text: Give up after the first relapse
Multiple failed attempts but keep trying
Gradual reduction with some setbacks
Cold turkey and stick to it

questions.text: Your group is making a decision that will negatively impact someone not present. You:

options.text: Go along with the group's decision
Ask if we should check with them first
Suggest waiting until they can be included
Speak up for the absent person's interests

questions.text: Your romantic partner does something that really bothers you. You:

options.text: Decide it's not worth fighting about
Hint at your displeasure and hope they figure it out
Wait until you're both calm and relaxed to discuss it
Bring it up as soon as possible

questions.text: A friend asks to borrow a significant amount of money. What do you actually do?

options.text: Make an excuse about not having it available
Offer a smaller amount or alternative help
Ask for details about why they need it first
Lend it immediately if you have it

questions.text: You're crying in public. What do you actually do?

options.text: Fight to hold it back at all costs
Make a joke about it to deflect
Find somewhere private immediately
Let it happen - emotions are human

questions.text: Your city offers free creative workshops (pottery, writing, dance, etc.). What's your actual pattern?

options.text: No interest - you have better things to do
Consider it but never actually register
Only go if a friend drags you along
Sign up for multiple workshops enthusiastically

questions.text: You said you'd do something but now you don't want to. What happens?

options.text: Ghost and deal with consequences later
Find a legitimate reason to cancel
Be honest that you changed your mind
Do it anyway - you gave your word

questions.text: Someone in your group consistently interrupts others. You:

options.text: Feel annoyed but don't say anything
Wait and see if anyone else addresses it
Try to redirect: 'What do you think, Sarah?'
Call it out directly: 'Let them finish'

questions.text: Your team is brainstorming and someone builds on your idea to make it much better. You:

options.text: Step back and let them run with it
Feel a bit territorial about your original concept
Add more to build on their improvement
Feel excited that the idea is improving

questions.text: You need help with something you're struggling with. What's your actual behavior?

options.text: Struggle alone until absolutely desperate
Research solutions yourself before asking anyone
Drop hints hoping someone offers help
Ask for help as soon as you realize you need it

questions.text: Your boss asks you to do something that goes against your personal principles but isn't illegal. You:

options.text: Do it without question - they're the boss
Express your concerns but do it anyway
Ask if there's another way to achieve the same goal
Refuse and explain why you can't do it

questions.text: A close friend is going through a tough time and keeps venting to you. You:

options.text: Encourage them to talk to a professional
Listen but set some boundaries about when you're available
Try to help them find solutions to their problems
Listen and offer emotional support whenever they need it

questions.text: Your group is celebrating something but you're going through a tough time personally. You:

options.text: Find a reason to leave early
Try to focus on their joy to lift your spirits
Join in the celebration despite how you feel
Share that you're struggling and might not be fully present

questions.text: Someone betrayed your trust in the past. How does it actually affect new relationships?

options.text: You're much more guarded with everyone
You trust but verify everything now
You test people extensively before trusting
You give each new person a fresh start

questions.text: Someone makes a comment that goes against your core values. You:

options.text: Change the subject to avoid conflict
Share your own values without attacking theirs
Ask questions to understand their perspective
Challenge their viewpoint directly

questions.text: Someone cuts in line in front of you. You:

options.text: Say nothing but feel annoyed
Assume they didn't notice and give them the benefit of the doubt
Loudly call them out for cutting
Politely point out that there's a line

questions.text: There's obvious tension in your friend group that everyone's ignoring. You:

options.text: Wait for someone else to address it
Try to lighten the mood and distract from the tension
Talk to individuals privately to understand what's happening
Bring it up openly: 'Can we talk about the elephant in the room?'

questions.text: You wake up not feeling great. What determines if you push through your day?

options.text: Any excuse to take it easy
Depends who's counting on you
Assess honestly and adjust accordingly
Push through regardless - duties first

questions.text: In your hobby group, someone with more experience consistently dismisses your ideas. You:

options.text: Defer to their experience and stay quiet
Find a different group where your input is valued
Ask them to explain why they think your ideas won't work
Continue sharing ideas despite their dismissiveness

questions.text: In a competitive situation, someone is clearly cheating or bending rules. You:

options.text: Lose interest in the competition
Try to beat them despite their advantage
Report it to the appropriate authority
Call them out immediately

questions.text: Someone gets emotional and starts crying during a discussion. You:

options.text: Feel uncomfortable and unsure what to do
Suggest taking a break for them to compose themselves
Give them space while staying present
Immediately offer comfort and support

dimensions.name: Openness
dimensions.description: Curiosity, creativity, imagination, and willingness to try new experiences

interpretation.high: You're intellectually curious and enjoy exploring new ideas, experiences, and creative pursuits. You appreciate complexity and abstract thinking.
interpretation.medium: You balance traditional approaches with occasional openness to new experiences. You're selectively curious about certain topics.
interpretation.low: You prefer familiar, conventional approaches and concrete, practical matters over abstract ideas.

interpretation.high: You're highly organized, disciplined, and reliable. You plan ahead, follow through on commitments, and maintain high standards.
interpretation.medium: You balance structure with flexibility. You're generally organized but can adapt when needed.
interpretation.low: You prefer spontaneity and flexibility over rigid planning. You work best without too much structure.

dimensions.name: Extraversion
dimensions.description: Social energy, assertiveness, and enthusiasm in interpersonal situations

interpretation.high: You're energized by social interaction, enjoy taking initiative in groups, and naturally engage with others. You're comfortable with attention and leadership.
interpretation.medium: You enjoy both social interaction and solitude. You can lead when needed but also appreciate following.
interpretation.low: You prefer smaller gatherings or one-on-one interactions. You need time alone to recharge and may avoid being the center of attention.

dimensions.name: Agreeableness
dimensions.description: Cooperation, empathy, trust, and concern for social harmony

interpretation.high: You're naturally cooperative, empathetic, and prioritize maintaining harmony in relationships. You're trusting and considerate of others' needs.
interpretation.medium: You balance cooperation with standing up for yourself. You're generally friendly but can be assertive when needed.
interpretation.low: You're comfortable with conflict and prioritize honesty over harmony. You're skeptical and maintain firm boundaries.

dimensions.name: Emotional Stability
dimensions.description: Resilience, emotional regulation, and stress management (inverse of Neuroticism)

interpretation.high: You handle stress well, remain calm under pressure, and don't take things too personally. You're emotionally resilient.
interpretation.medium: You experience normal emotional ups and downs but generally manage them effectively. You're somewhat sensitive to stress.
interpretation.low: You're more sensitive to stress and criticism. You experience emotions intensely and may worry frequently about potential problems.

sections.heading: Your Personality Dimensions
sections.content: Based on your responses across 60 different life scenarios

sections.heading: Strengths & Natural Tendencies
sections.content: Your highest scoring dimensions reveal your natural strengths

sections.heading: Growth Opportunities
sections.content: Areas where developing new strategies could enhance your wellbeing

sections.heading: Personalized Recommendations
sections.content: Resources and next steps based on your unique profile
